Main Tools¶

internals.py: Classes module for the VEnCode project

class internals.BarakatTS2018Data(source='BarakatTS2018', **kwargs)¶

Data from Barakat, et al., Cell Stem Cell, 2018. Parsed to use in VEnCode validation studies.

How to use: data = internals.BarakatTS2018Data(**kwargs) kwargs can be empty, or used to get only part of the data, by using the kwarg: data=”core” for example. data available are: core and extended enhancers, merged enhancers. Check Barakat, et al., Cell Stem Cell, 2018.

class internals.Bed(source=False)¶

Parses data from BED files to use in VEnCode validation studies.

How to use: data = internals.Bed(source) source can be any source described in baseclass, or a filename ending in .BED

class internals.BroadPeak(source=False)¶

Parses data from BroadPeak files to use in VEnCode validation studies.

How to use: data = internals.BroadPeak(source) source can be any source described in baseclass, or a filename ending in .broadPeak

class internals.ChristensenCL2014Data(source='ChristensenCL2014', **kwargs)¶

Parses data from Christensen CL, et al., Cancer Cell, 2014, to use in VEnCode validation studies.

How to use: data = internals.ChristensenCL2014Data(**kwargs) kwargs can be empty, or used to get only part of the data, by using the kwarg: data=”H82” for example. data available are: GLC16, H82, and H69.

class internals.Csv(source=False, positions=0, 0, 0, 1, splits=':', '-')¶

Parses data from CSV files to use in VEnCode validation studies.

How to use: data = internals.Csv(source) source can be any source described in baseclass, or a filename ending in .csv.

class internals.DataTpm(file='custom', sep=',', nrows=None, files_path=None, **kwargs)¶

An Object representing a data set to retrieve VEnCodes from. Contains optional filtering methods and other tools.

target_ctp¶

The target.

Type

str

add_celltype(celltypes=False, data_from='custom', **kwargs)¶

Adds expression data for celltypes from other data sets (with similar regulatory element information). Examples include adding data from a cancer cell type to a primary cell type data set.

Parameters

  • celltypes – Cell types to merge with the DataTpm data. If false it will add all provided data.

  • data_from – Data containing the cell types to add. “custom” will open a file dialog.

Optional parameters (**kwargs) are used to create a new DataTpm object from “data_from” to add to the data set. So, if that is the case, check DataTpm documentation.

binarize_data(threshold=0)¶

Converts all data to 0 and 1, where 1 is any value above threshold. :param threshold: max value for “0”

copy(deep=True)¶

Method to generate a shallow, or deep copy of DataTpmFantom5 object

Parameters

deep (bool) – True if deep copy.

Returns

a copy of the DataTpmFantom5 object

define_non_target_celltypes_inactivity(threshold=0)¶

Converts the data to binary (0 - inactive; 1- active) given a threshold. :param threshold: Maximum TPM non-target cell types should have to be considered inactive.

filter_by_reg_element_sparseness(threshold=90)¶

Applies a filter to the Data, retaining only the regulatory elements in which xth percentile (x being the threshold variable) value is 0 (that is: not expressed). This filter will, then, retain only the REs with most 0 TPM for all celltypes.

Parameters

threshold (int) – percentile value used to filter the data.

filter_by_target_celltype_activity(threshold=1, donors='all', binarize=True)¶

Applies a filter to the Data, retaining only the regulatory elements that are expressed in the celltype of interest at >= x TPM, x being the threshold variable.

Parameters

  • float] threshold (Union[int,) – TPM value used to filter the data.

  • donors (list) – used to select only a few donors out of all from target celltype.

  • binarize – Convert target cell type expression to 0 and 1, for values below or above the threshold,

respectively

make_data_celltype_specific(target_celltypes)¶

Determines celltype/donors (columns) of interest to analyse later.

Parameters

target_celltypes – the celltype to target for analysis

remove_celltype(celltypes, merged=True)¶

Removes a specific celltype from data

Parameters

  • celltypes – celltype/s to remove. int or list-type

  • merged – If the data has been previously merged into celltypes, True. If columns represent donors, False.

remove_element(elements)¶

Removes a specific celltype from data

Parameters

elements – regulatory element/s to remove. int or list-type

property shape¶

Gives the shape of the data’s data frame :return: The shape in (rows, cols) of the data

sort_columns(col_to_shift=None, pos_to_move=None)¶

Sorts columns alphabetically

sort_sparseness()¶

Sorts the data by descending sparsest RE

to_csv(*args, **kwargs)¶

Generates a csv file. args and kwargs passed must be compatible to Pandas DataFrame.to_csv()

class internals.DataTpmFantom5(file='custom', sample_types='primary cells', data_type='promoters', keep_raw=False, nrows=None, files_path='test', *args, **kwargs)¶

An Object specifically representing the initial FANTOM5 CAGE-seq data set with some universal data treatment and with optional filtering methods.

add_celltype(celltypes=False, data_from='custom', sample_types='cell lines', fantom=True, **kwargs)¶

Adds expression data for celltypes from other data sets (with similar regulatory element information). Examples include adding data from a cancer cell type to a primary cell type data set.

Parameters

  • celltypes – Cell types to merge with the DataTpm data. If false it will add all provided data.

  • data_from – Data containing the cell types to add. “custom” will open a file dialog.

  • sample_types – sample type (“primary cells”, for e.g.) of the data set to add.

  • fantom – is your data to add from FANTOM5 CAGE-seq? if so put True. Else, False.

Optional parameters (**kwargs) are used to create a new DataTpm object from “data_from” to add to the data set. So, if that is the case, check DataTpm documentation.

make_data_celltype_specific(target_celltypes, supersets={'CD14+ CD16+ Monocytes': 'CD14+ Monocytes', 'CD14+ CD16- Monocytes': 'CD14+ Monocytes', 'CD4+CD25+CD45RA+ naive regulatory T cells': 'CD4+ T Cells', 'CD4+CD25+CD45RA- memory regulatory T cells': 'CD4+ T Cells', 'CD4+CD25-CD45RA+ naive conventional T cells': 'CD4+ T Cells', 'CD4+CD25-CD45RA- memory conventional T cells': 'CD4+ T Cells'})¶

Determines celltype/donors (columns) of interest to analyse later. For previously parsed files, opens the specific file for that celltype.

Parameters

  • target_celltypes – the celltype to target for analysis

  • supersets (dict) – when a celltype is a subset of other, we must remove that superset celltype to analyse

the subset.

merge_donors_primary(exclude_target=True)¶

Applies a more conservative, but faster approach to data set mining: cell type columns are created by merging all donors for that cell type. The value for the merged column corresponds the average of all donors.

remove_celltype(celltypes, merged=True)¶

Removes a specific celltype from data

Parameters

  • celltypes – celltype/s to remove. int or list-type

  • merged – If the data has been previously merged into celltypes, True. If columns represent donors, False.

class internals.DataTpmFantom5Validated(validate_with, *args, **kwargs)¶

This class provides methods to develop a data set with chromosome coordinates intercepted with those of validate_with, which we call validated regulatory elements.

How to use: After initializing, filter data with validated REs by calling the “select_validated” method.

select_validated()¶

Main method to filter the REs in the data, leaving in the data only those that match the external data set.

class internals.Fasta(source=False)¶

Parses data from FASTA files to use in VEnCode validation studies.

How to use: data = internals.Fasta(source) source can be any source described in baseclass, or a filename ending in .Fasta, .Fa, .txt, etc.

class internals.InoueF2017Data(source='InoueF2017')¶

Data from Inoue F, et al., Genome Res., 2017. Parsed to use in VEnCode validation studies.

How to use: data = internals.InoueF2017Data()

static search_between_brackets(string)¶

Gets all text between the first [] in a string. :param string: String to search for text. :return: All text between []

class internals.OutsideData(folder=None)¶

Base class for all data from outside sources.

property data_source¶

File name of the data. :return: File name of the data

join_data_sets(data_set)¶

Joins the data from this source with data from a different source. The result is a filtered data set with just the genomic coordinates that are overlapping in both data sets. :param data_set: the data set to merge with.

class internals.Vencodes(data_object, algorithm, number_of_re=4, n_samples=10000, stop=5, second_data_object=None, using=None)¶

An Object representing the VEnCodes found for a specific celltype

determine_e_values(repetitions=100)¶

Call this function to generate e-values for the current VEnCodes. E-values will be stored in the variable called e_values. Method applied to calculate e-values is a Monte-Carlo simulation.

Parameters

repetitions (int) – number of times each vencode is evaluated to get the average value.

export(*args, **kwargs)¶

Call this method to export vencode related values to a .csv file.

exporting e-values: - use “e-values” in the args to export the e-values. - Use: >> e-values = path to define a specific path for the file. (must be a complete path)

Parameters

  • args – “e-values”, “TPP” or a list/tuple with both.

  • kwargs – optional args to apply, see description.

get_vencode_data(method='return', path=None)¶

Call this function to get the VEnCode data in .csv format (method=”write”) or just printed in terminal (method=”print”), or both (method=”both”). Alternatively, it can return the data to a variable (method=”return”).

Parameters

  • method (str) – how to retrieve the data.

  • path (str) – path to write a file to store the VEnCode data.

heuristic2_vencode()¶

Call this function to generate the next VEnCode, possibly hybrid enhancer-promoter VEnCode. The VEnCode is appended to the variable self.vencodes.

next(amount=1)¶

Call this function to generate the next VEnCode. The VEnCode is appended to the variable self.vencodes, or can be returned as a variable.

Parameters

amount (int) – number of vencodes to get.

Returns

a list containing the desired amount of vencodes.

next_heuristic2_vencode(second_data_object, amount=1)¶

Call this function to generate the next VEnCode, possibly hybrid enhancer-promoter VEnCode. The VEnCode is appended to the variable self.vencodes. :param second_data_object:

static vencode_mc_simulation(data, reps=100)¶

Simulates turning 0s to 1s over a data set and asks if the data still represents a VEnCode.

Parameters

  • data (pd.DataFrame) – Data frame of promoter expression per celltype without the celltype of interest.

  • reps (int) – number of simulations to run.

Returns

e_values, that is, the average number of random changes done to the data that breaks the vencode.

view_vencodes(method='print', interpolation='nearest', path=None, snapshot=None)¶

Call this function to get an heat map visualization of the vencodes.

Parameters

  • method (str) – “print” to get visualization on terminal. “write” to write to a file. “both” for both.

  • interpolation (str) – method for heat map interpolation

  • path (str) – Optional path for the file.

  • snapshot (int) – Number of celltypes to show in heat map. False gets all but may hinder visualization.
